bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, February 24, 1938

div1.p: Moran will send Hench a photograph of himself at no charge, and returns Hench's check. He offers Hench advice on contacting other yellow fever survivors and politely refuses medical treatment for his duodenal ulcer.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, February 24, 1938
div1.opener:
Havana, Feb. 24, 1938.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Please do not think I have willingly or wittingly failed to
respond in the desired form to your letter dated January 27th. It so happens
that December, January, February and March of each year are our busy months
in Cuba. Preparation for the “grinding season” commences in December and the
other three months are devoted to actual grinding by the sugar mills of the
Island. Since we have several sugar mills to which we supply lubricating oils
and greases, considerable of my time is devoted to our sugar mill customers in
the months indicated. Most of the mills have offices in Havana, but none the
less we have to keep in touch with the engineers and mechanics. That means
visiting the mills, scattered over the six provinces of the Island. Only three
days ago was I able to get around to have that photograph taken for you. They
are promised for Saturday, the 26th, but I may not be able to have them ready
before Monday, the 28th. As soon as they are delivered to me I will mail one
or two to you, together with a picture I had taken overseas during the World
War and another which I had taken around 1910 for the late Joseph Bucklin Bishop
for his book “The Panama Gateway”. I regret I have no photographs or snapshots
of any kind taken at the time of the yellow fever experiments. I had quite a
few such, taken in uniform and as a civilian, but as they began to fade over the
years, I gradually threw them overboard. Being more or less of a soldier of
fortune, since I arrived in the land of Washington and Lincoln, the throwing
overboard usually took place when I was in the process of packing my trunks.
Except during the past ten years or so, I have carried my wardrobe and personal
belongings in trunks. So much to serve as an alibi for my failure to attend,
without delay, to your appreciated and courteous request.

I am returning the ceheck you sent me. It was most thoughtful
and delicate of you to have sent it. In an effort to emulate your delicacy, I
am returning it. From this you must not assume that I am offended. While I
am sometimes “touchy” in such matters, it does not happen to apply in the present
instance. I am more than pleased to have the photograph taken for you at my
own expense.

The following are all the additional addresses I have been
able to obtain for you, to date, of the survivors who took the tests:
Clyde L. West, Riverdale, Md.
Capt. Thomas M. England, Medical Administration Corps,
U. S. Army, Office of the Surgeon, Governors Island, N. Y. H.
Dr. Robert P. Cooke, State Dept. of Health, Lexington, Va.
John R. Bullard, St. Augustine, Florida.
With the four listed, plus Kissinger, Andrus, Hanberry and your humble servant,
you should be able to get in touch with at least eight of the survivors. There
is some doubt as to whether or not Folk is still in the land of the living.
Covington and Forbes are presumed to be still alive. Of the 22 names on the
Roll of Honor, the known dead number eleven, including the four members of the
“Reed & Carroll” Yellow Fever Commission. My own impression is that there are
ten survivors in all at the present writing. I think that if you were to
write to the Veterans Administration, Washington, D. C., listing the three

Feb. 24, 1938
supposed survivors whose addresses you do not have, instructions would be
given you in al letter as to how you might be able to get in touch with them.
The Director of Finance, Veterans Administration, send checks each month to
the survivors or their widows, but will not supply their addresses. The
procedure is to write to the party in whom you may be interested, placing a
stamp on your letter, envelope to bear the name only of such party. That
letter should be inclosed in an envelope addressed to the Director of Finance,
Veterans Administration, Washington, D. C., who will complete the mailing
address on the enclosed envelope and forward same to destination. The envelope
in which the letter for the “missing link” is inclosed must bear no return
address. It must be entirely plain. The address will be shown on your own
letter enclosed in the plain envelope, with nothing else on the envelope itself
except the bare name and surname of the man with whom you want to get in touch.
He may reply to your letter if he chooses. Chances are that any of the survivors
to whom you might write would reply to your letter. The War Department rules
in the matter of furnishing addresses are most rigid. Some months ago, I
tried to get the names of the survivors for my own use and I have given you
the gist of the “red tape” which has to be gone through in order to accomplish
such a purpose. As a matter of fact I wanted the addresses of the survivors
for you. I am under the impression that the Director of Finance would not
object to inform you as to which on the list you submit are still in the land
of the living. I am not sure that he will even do that. However, if you
are sufficiently interested, there would be no harm in trying.

I have followed out your suggestions with reference to Mr.
Andrus' case and chances are that you will be hearing from him before many
days go by. Poor fellow, I do wish so much that something could be done for
him to the end of releasing him from his present sorry state. I am more
than delighted, for his sake, that his case comes within the lines in which you
specialize. As to my own case, my dear friend, I fear me very much that I will
have to worry along. I have a premonition that if I should ever be placed on
the operating table for an operation on my stomach, I would not survive the
operation. My heart action is none too good. Years ago, when I was Medical
Supply Officer on the Panama Canal, I was operated upon for appendicitis and
was back on duty on the morning of the eighth day dating from my first entry
into the hospital. Being inventory time, I could not see my way clear to take
the fifteen days which convalescents were recommended and advised to take at the
“Taboga Island Sanitarium” of the Medical Department. That was some thirty
years ago. So far as I know a man by the name of Cummings and myself were the
only two operated upon for appendicitis on the Panama Canal to hold the seven-
day record, and there were many of them when the force on the Panama Canal
had reached 50,000 men and women employees. I have told you this so that you
may not brand me as too cowardly to run the risk of an operation. Please
accept my sincre thanks for your offer of assistance to me in connection with
my gastric ulcer. By watching my diet and sidestepping excesses I may last
for several years yet. When the crucial moment arrives, my only hope is that
it will not be preceded by long and painful suffering. Please forgive me for
this long, rambling, semi-sentimental letter. You are too busy a man to wade
through such a long and purposeless letter.
